name: 2-vinylbenzoic acid
Reason: 2-vinylbenzoic acid has a melting point influenced by its functional groups relative to the base of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a vinyl group and a carboxylic acid functional group. The vinyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in dipole interactions and raise the melting point by approximately +10 °C. The carboxylic acid group introduces a hydroxyl group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and raise the melting point by approximately +5 °C. The presence of a methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and the capacity for hydrogen bonding. The methoxy group raises the melting point by approximately +5 °C.
